In proof theory, one of the fundamental proofs is the Law of Excluded Middle (LEM). For a math student, the problem can be: 

Prove that the Law of Excluded Middle holds for any mathematical statement `P` by showing that `P ∨ ¬P` is always true, given any `P`.
message_2:
To prove the Law of Excluded Middle (LEM) for any mathematical statement `P`, we need to show that `P ∨ ¬P` is always true, given any `P`. 

The Law of Excluded Middle states that for any proposition `P`, either `P` is true or its negation `¬P` is true. In other words, there is no middle ground between `P` and `¬P`. 

Proof:

Consider an arbitrary proposition `P`. There are two possibilities: 

1. `P` is true.
2. `P` is false.

If `P` is true, then `P ∨ ¬P` is true because the disjunction `∨` is true if at least one of its components is true. In this case, `P` is true, so `P ∨ ¬P` is true.

If `P` is false, then its negation `¬P` is true. In this case, `P ∨ ¬P` is also true because the disjunction `∨` is true if at least one of its components is true. Since `¬P` is true, `P ∨ ¬P` is true.

In both cases, we have shown that `P ∨ ¬P` is true. Therefore, the Law of Excluded Middle holds for any mathematical statement `P`.
